EN

The article features insights from Dor Eligula of BridgeWise regarding the integration of AI and human judgment in investment research to support brokers and exchanges. Eligula identifies significant growth opportunities in Asian markets driven by local client behavior and discusses overlooked areas for broker expansion. Additionally, the text includes an interview with Brendan Callan, CEO of TRADU, who critiques the current proprietary trading model, arguing that it is overly reliant on fees, lacks strict risk management, and is confusing for retail traders.

Key Points

  • Dor Eligula highlights the collaboration between AI automation and human analysts in investment research.
  • Asian markets present 'blue ocean' growth opportunities due to specific local client behaviors.
  • Brendan Callan argues the current prop trading model is flawed due to fee dependence and poor risk management.

Article

Dor gives real examples of how automation and human judgment meet at Bridgewise ‚Äî including moments when analysts corrected AI output, and times when AI prevented an error. We close with a practical question: how retail investors can actually use AI without falling into common traps. Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Executive Interview | Brendan Callan | CEO, TRADU | FMLS:25 Brendan Callan joined us fresh off the Summit‚Äôs most anticipated debate: ‚ÄúIs Prop Trading Good for the Industry?‚Äù Brendan argued against the motion ‚Äî and the audience voted him the winner. In this interview, Brendan explains the reasoning behind his position. He walks through the message he believes many firms avoid: that the current prop trading model is too dependent on fees, too loose on risk, and too confusing for retail audiences. We discuss why he thinks the model grew fast, why it may run into walls, and what he believes is needed for a cleaner, more responsible version of prop trading. This is Brendan at his frankest ‚Äî sharp, grounded, and very clear about what changes are overdue.
